items.title: Get Started with Specbook
items.text: This guide will help you install and run Specbook in just a few minutes.

items.title: What You'll Need
items.text:
Before you start, make sure you have:

  • Python 3.11 or newer - Check your version by running python --version
  • uv - A fast Python package installer. Get it here

items.title: Installation
items.text:
Install Specbook from the command line:

uv tool install specbook --from git+https://github.com/chriscorrea/specbook.git

This adds the specbook command to your terminal. You can use it from any folder.

items.title: Your First SDD Project
items.text:
Specbook works best with projects that have a specs/ folder. Here's what a typical project might look like:

my-project/
├── specs/
│   ├── 001-user-login/
│   │   ├── spec.md
│   │   └── tasks.md
│   └── 002-dashboard/
│       └── spec.md
└── src/
    └── ... your code ...

items.title: Starting the Server
items.text:
Open your terminal, go to your project folder, and run:

specbook

That's it! Your browser will open to http://localhost:7732 where you can view and edit spec documents.

items.title: Spec-Driven Development
items.text:
Spec-driven development shifts the focus from writing code to defining thoughtful requirements that act as the actual blueprint for building software. This guide will explain the approach and share examples.

items.title: Advanced Usage
items.text: This guide introduces features and configuration options for experienced Specbook users.

items.title: Custom Port
items.text:
By default, Specbook runs on port 7732. You can change this:

# Start on a different port
specbook -p 8080

# Or with the serve command
specbook serve -p 8080

# Stop a server on a custom port
specbook stop -p 8080

Note that can run Specbook for different projects simultaneously by assigning different ports for each project.

# One project's documentation is available on default port
cd ~/projects/first-project
specbook

# Another project's documentation is available on port 8080
cd ~/projects/another-project
specbook -p 8080

items.title: Specification Structure
items.text:
A well-organized spec folder looks something like this:

specs/
├── 001-user-auth/
│   ├── spec.md          # main specification
│   ├── plan.md          # implementation plan
│   ├── tasks.md         # task list
│   └── research.md      # research notes
├── 002-dashboard/
│   └── spec.md
└── 003-reporting/
    ├── spec.md
    └── plan.md

items.title: Naming Conventions
items.text:
Specbook recognizes these standard document types:

Filename Purpose spec.md Feature specification with requirements plan.md Technical implementation plan tasks.md Detailed task breakdown research.md Background research and decisions data-model.md Data structures and relationships quickstart.md Testing and validation scenarios

You can add other markdown files too - Specbook will display them alongside the standard documents.

items.title: Document Status
items.text:
Specbook infers each document's status through optional YAML frontmatter:

---
status: implementing
---

# My Feature Spec
...

Available statuses: - draft - in-review - approved - implementing - complete

items.title: Inline Editing
items.text:
The following keyboard shortcuts are available in edit mode: - Cmd/Ctrl + S - Save changes - Cmd/Ctrl + B - Bold selected text - Cmd/Ctrl + I - Italicize selected text - Escape - Cancel editing
